Additionally, a saccular aneurysm was discovered in the left cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery through a CT angiogram. The patient was diagnosed with a saccular aneurysm of the left cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery, a vascular anomaly located in the brain. To address this condition, the patient underwent high-flow extracranial-intracranial (EC-IC) bypass surgery and aneurysm ligation. The procedure, performed through a left pterional craniotomy, involved the use of a saphenous vein graft for the bypass, and the ligation of the left internal carotid artery in the neck. Following the surgery, the patient's recovery has been good with no complications, leading to a stable discharge. Over the course of one year of follow-up, the patient has reported no further episodes of epistaxis or other complaints, indicating a favorable functional status.

Mr. Smith, a patient admitted to the intensive care unit, has recently been diagnosed with encapsulating peritoneal fibrosis, a peritoneal disorder affecting the abdominal cavity. This condition arose after Mr. Smith experienced septic shock due to a bowel perforation. Prior to this, he had a history of nephrosclerosis, which led to renal insufficiency. Currently, Mr. Smith's treatment involves the use of prednisolone and tamoxifen, alongside intermittent hemodialysis via a brachio-cephalic fistula. However, during his recovery, he developed septic shock and had to undergo continuous venovenous hemofiltration and receive vasoactive support. Unfortunately, his discharge status remains unstable. As the medical team continues to monitor Mr. Smith's progress, he is currently undergoing hemofiltration through his brachio-cephalic fistula, with ongoing follow-up and further assessments ahead.

Introducing John Doe, a 45-year-old male who presented with acute bilateral hearing loss, non-pulsatile sound, and tinnitus, along with progressively decreasing hearing over the course of three days. Notably, he reported a marked worsening of his hearing during this time. Of his medical history, he underwent rhinoplasty nine months earlier and experienced acute watery diarrhea in the past week. Physical examination revealed mild tenderness in both feet upon light touch. Otoscopic examination indicated normal ear canals and tympanic membranes, while neurological examination findings were unremarkable. Laboratory tests, including hematologic and biochemical parameters, were all normal, and rheumatoid factor levels were negative. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, serologic studies for autoimmune diseases, and viral markers were also within normal ranges. Audiometry revealed a sensorineural hearing loss with a 30-dB loss at three consecutive frequencies. The diagnosis of idiopathic sudden sensorineural hearing loss was established, noting its bilateral location. Empiric treatment was initiated, consisting of bilateral intratympanic dexamethasone, oral prednisolone, oral acyclovir, methotrexate, pentoxifylline, and folic acid. John experienced gradual improvement of his hearing and is currently undergoing ongoing treatment and monitoring for this condition. Further follow-up will be conducted to ensure his recovery is progressing as expected.

In this patient's medical journey, they have faced multiple challenges due to various symptoms and deformities. They came to the clinic with complaints of multiple swellings in the back and arms, as well as deformity in both great toes since birth. At the age of two, they experienced painless swelling in their left proximal arm, accompanied by restricted extension of the left elbow joint and restricted movements in the right arm. Additionally, the patient presented with multiple swellings in the bilateral infrascapular regions, which severely limited their activities of daily living. Their medical history revealed a prior surgery for a swelling on the left arm that resulted in persistent restriction in movements. Diagnostic findings through various radiographic tests unveiled heterotopic ossification in the soft tissues around both humeri, extending through the axilla to the chest wall. The patient also exhibited heterotopic ossification along the left side of the neck, broadening of the femoral neck with bridge-like heterotopic ossifications extending across both hip joints, a bony outgrowth appearance due to ossification along ligamentous insertions in the knees, and bilateral hallux valgus with monophalangism of the great toes. Consequently, the diagnosis of fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva, a rare genetic disorder, was made, specifically affecting the bilateral great toes, arms, back, and hips. As for the treatment, the patient received supportive care and counseling regarding the prognosis and the absence of definitive treatment options. Their postoperative course had no significant complications, resulting in a discharge in good condition. However, the patient's follow-up is of lifelong duration, emphasizing the importance of connecting with support groups like IFOPA for advocacy and continuous support.

Introducing Mr. Smith, a patient who presented with end-stage osteoarthritis in the left hip and underwent total hip arthroplasty. Unfortunately, during the surgery, he experienced a fracture of the greater trochanter. However, subsequent diagnostic findings revealed satisfactory orientation of hip prosthesis components and successful fixation of the fractured trochanter. Mr. Smith's medical history did not indicate any significant previous health issues. Postoperatively, he showed excellent range of movement, no tenderness, and experienced an uneventful recovery. The six-month follow-up confirmed the prosthesis functioning well and equally good news was obtained from the 24-month follow-up radiographs, where Mr. Smith was reported as a pain-free patient with the ability to mobilize unaided. His treatment involved cementless total hip arthroplasty with ceramic components, with additional fracture fixation using partially threaded screws. A subsequent revision surgery was performed to exchange ceramic components, along with the reattachment of atrophic abductors. Considering his favorable postoperative course and satisfactory outcomes, Mr. Smith was discharged in good condition. It is vital to note that throughout the 24-month follow-up period, he remained pain-free and demonstrated the ability to move independently.

Introducing Mr. Smith, a 65-year-old gentleman who recently came to our clinic with two chief complaints. Firstly, he reported experiencing claudication in his right leg after walking just 300 meters, leading to discomfort and hindered mobility. Additionally, he was concerned about a weak pulse he noticed in his right groin and ankle. Examining his medical history, we discovered that Mr. Smith had undergone a coronary artery bypass graft operation two years ago, which suggested a potential link to his current condition. Further investigations, including color Doppler ultrasonography and angiograms, revealed an occlusion in his right external iliac artery while his right common iliac and common femoral arteries remained patent. Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with an external iliac artery steal syndrome, a vascular disease primarily affecting his right lower extremity. To address this issue, he underwent endovascular stent placement using a self-expanding nitinol stent as the primary treatment. Following the procedure, Mr. Smith experienced complete resolution of his claudication symptoms. He was discharged on the same day with instructions to take acetyl salicylic acid. In the one-month follow-up, it was observed that he had achieved complete recovery from his erectile dysfunction, while his functional status remained robust.

Introducing Ms. Smith, an active and otherwise healthy individual who recently experienced a sudden and debilitating pain at the superior pole of her patella, rendering her unable to walk. Her medical history reveals a previous traumatic injury from a fall, which might have contributed to her current condition. Diagnostic findings, including an X-ray, CT-scan, and MRI, revealed a sleeve fracture of the upper pole of the patella, accompanied by patella baja and an avulsed fragment. Additionally, a shell of bone proximal to the patella and a quadriceps tendon rupture with cartilaginous injury were identified. To address these issues, Ms. Smith underwent open surgical procedures for reconstituting the fracture and repairing the quadriceps tendon. Details of the treatment involved resetting the patella fracture piece, wire fixation, and suturing of the joint capsule and quadriceps tendon. Following the surgery, Ms. Smith's recovery has been remarkable, with the restoration of knee function and a return to normal appearance. She has been discharged in good condition and is anticipated to have a follow-up duration of 6 months. At present, she has fully regained the capacity for normal walking and flexion of 120 degrees.

In a tale of pain and resilience, this patient arrived at our medical facility with a litany of complaints: pain in the abdomen, excessive tiredness, and even vomiting of blood. The cause became clear as their medical history unfolded - a previous Grade III liver injury from a fall off a moving truck. Diagnostic findings painted a vivid picture of their current condition, revealing a pseudoaneurysm of the right hepatic artery with a ruptured hematoma in liver segments VI, VII, and VIII. To complicate matters further, a chest X-ray showed consolidation in the right lower lobe. Puzzles pieced together, the diagnosis became apparent: post-traumatic bronchobiliary fistula, a complication arising from the liver injury, nestled in the right hepatic lobe near the diaphragm. Our course of action was swift yet precise: coil embolization of the hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm using three coils. The patient's postoperative journey proved successful as their cough and bilioptysis resolved, culminating in their discharge on the third day following the procedure. To ensure noteworthy progress, a follow-up spanning two months attested to the complete resolution of the hematoma, restoring the patient's functional status once more.

In a concerning turn of events, a patient presented with complaints of a mass on the left rostral maxilla and dorsolateral muzzle. Following diagnostic procedures including a CT scan and biopsy, it was revealed that the patient was dealing with a histologically low-grade, biologically high-grade soft tissue sarcoma, specifically known as histologically low-grade, biologically high-grade FSA (H/L FSA). The location of this soft tissue sarcoma was in the left rostral maxilla and dorsolateral muzzle. To address this condition, a composite resection was performed, utilizing a combined intra- and extraoral approach, involving the removal of both soft tissue and bone. The procedure also included the extraction of the distal root of the left maxillary fourth premolar tooth. Fortunately, the patient's postoperative course was uneventful, resulting in a good condition upon discharge. A follow-up period of 3 months revealed no evidence of recurrence, demonstrating that the patient is doing well at home.

This young patient presents with a rather uncommon concern regarding painless swelling of the gums, both in the upper and lower regions of their teeth, which has persisted for the past three months. Additionally, they have been experiencing bleeding while brushing. After a thorough examination, no significant medical history or diagnostic findings were identified. The patient's treatment plan consisted of using topical steroids, antiseptic mouthwashes, and antihistamines, which provided temporary relief. Following a gingivectomy in the maxillary gingiva, mild improvement was observed during their postoperative course. The patient's symptoms improved over the course of seven days, leading to their functional status being classified as improved during follow-up.

Mr. Johnson presents with a complex medical history involving abdominal wall hernia and recurrence after an initial surgery, as well as a series of work accidents, including one in May 2008 while lifting a transformer. His occupation as an electrical assembler in an industrial electrical panel manufacturing company required him to frequently carry pieces weighing between 20 to 100 kg, with or without the assistance of trolleys. Unfortunately, these demanding job duties resulted in the development of epigastric and umbilical hernias with necrosis in the mesenteric and abdominal wall fat. Mr. Johnson underwent emergency open surgery in May 2008, which confirmed the presence of these hernias and necrosis. Following his initial surgery, he had a normal postoperative evaluation; however, the hernia recurred, leading to a second surgery. This time, a prosthetic repair of the defect was performed. Thankfully, Mr. Johnson's recovery was successful, and he was able to return to work, although with lifelong limitations for heavy lifting. Regular postoperative follow-up visits have shown no decrease in his functional status, and he continues to work without a decrease in wage.

Once upon a time in a not-so-distant medical clinic, a patient presented with non-specific respiratory symptoms, accompanied by a brief episode of apnea during sleep. This individual had no history of previous injuries. Upon investigation, a chest X-ray revealed significant cardiomegaly, prompting further diagnostic examinations. An echocardiogram unveiled a giant right atrial aneurysm measuring 7 × 6 cm and a small left-to-right shunt across a patent foramen ovale. A subsequent cardiac MRI confirmed the presence of a giant thin-walled aneurysm spanning the entire free wall of the right atrium without intracavitary thrombus. The diagnosis of a congenital anomaly known as a giant right atrial aneurysm was made. To address this condition, the patient underwent surgical resection, including the removal of the massive aneurysm and closure of the patent foramen ovale. Postoperatively, the patient experienced a smooth recovery, with short non-sustained runs of ectopic atrial tachycardia controlled by Atenolol. Four days after surgery, they were discharged home, their cardiac size significantly reduced. A week later, a follow-up revealed the resolution of pericardial effusion and no new findings on the echocardiogram, indicating a positive functional status post-operation.

In the past three months, the patient presented with a rapidly-growing mass in the lower anterior neck along with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Their medical history reveals a previous diagnosis of a benign cystic thyroid nodule seven years ago. Diagnostic findings from an ultrasound scan reveal a 6×5 cm-sized, heterogeneously hypoechoic nodule with internal calcification in the left lobe of the thyroid gland. A CT scan further confirms a large, low-attenuating mass has replaced the left thyroid gland, extending to the level of the hyoid bone with invasion to the trachea. The diagnosis reveals that this is a case of synovial sarcoma, a type of soft tissue sarcoma located in the thyroid gland. To address this, the patient underwent total thyroidectomy with tracheal fenestration, along with a biopsy for further examination. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in good condition. However, two months later, the patient unfortunately passed away due to unknown causes.

In this medical record, we encounter a patient who has been experiencing a progressive flattening of the left side of their face since the age of 2. Additionally, the patient presents with pigmentation on the left side of their face since birth, along with hypoplasia of the left malar region, atrophy of the left masseter muscle and fat, and prominence of the left infraorbital ridge and zygoma. Furthermore, the patient displays enophthalmos, a depression of the left eye socket, as well as a deviation of the mouth angle to the affected side at rest, and pigmentation on the left cheek and palpebral conjunctiva. Diagnostic findings from panoramic radiographs indicate no significant abnormalities, while axial and coronal CT images reveal hypoplasia of the left zygomatic complex, maxillary sinus, and lateral orbital wall, alongside left enophthalmos. A three-dimensional reconstruction CT image shows a deviated nasal septum, tilt in the occlusal table, and zygomatic complex, as well as a hypoplastic orbital wall on the left side. Based on these findings, the patient has been diagnosed with Parry-Romberg syndrome, a facial atrophy syndrome affecting the left side of the face. At this stage, the patient's medical history remains unreported. Treatment details, postoperative course, and follow-up information are also absent from the available information.

Introducing Mr. Smith, a patient who recently presented with two concerning complaints: urinary retention for a prolonged period of time and a pelvic mass. Further investigation revealed a sizable mass in the retroperitoneum extending into the left groin, accompanied by bilateral hydroureter and compression of the urinary bladder, as indicated by a CT scan. Additional testing through Fine Needle Aspiration confirmed the mass to be of spindle cell origin. Therefore, a diagnosis of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, specifically a spindle cell sarcoma, located in the pelvic area was made. To address this condition, Mr. Smith underwent an abdominal and pelvic exploration, accompanied by surgical excision of the pelvic sarcoma. Remarkably, his bladder was spared, and only the left ureter remained unaffected. Postoperatively, the patient has shown a good recovery, although specific details regarding his discharge status were not provided. The duration and functional status of the follow-up have also not been specified at this time. Nonetheless, Mr. Smith's presentation, diagnosis, and surgical intervention demonstrate the comprehensive and tailored approach taken to address his condition while preserving his overall well-being.

In a perplexing medical tale, the patient initially presented with multiple swellings in the back and arms, along with a congenital deformity in both great toes. Over time, the patient experienced gradually increasing painless swelling in the left proximal arm at the age of two, and restricted movements in the right arm at the age of six. Furthermore, bilateral infrascapular swellings and restricted shoulder movements became evident, significantly impeding the patient's ability to perform daily activities such as feeding, dressing, and undressing. Previous orthopedic surgery was conducted to address the left arm swelling. Diagnostic findings through radiographs uncovered a perplexing condition called fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva, a genetic disorder characterized by bilateral great toe anomalies and widespread heterotopic ossification in various soft tissues including the humerus, chest wall, neck, pelvis, hips, knees, and foot. Unfortunately, this condition lacks a definite treatment, leaving symptomatic management as the only option. The patient was provided with counseling regarding the prognosis and referred to support groups. Currently, ongoing monitoring for disease progression and symptom management are integral parts of the patient's functional status.

Introducing this patient's journey, we find ourselves amid a tale of acute mediastinitis, empyema, and thoracotomy incision site infection, coupled with the onset of septic shock. Significant to note is their preexisting surgical treatment for esophageal rupture at another hospital. Diagnostic findings revealed the rather alarming flattening of the left rectus abdominis muscle on an abdominal computed tomography (CT). Consequently, the diagnosis indicates rectus abdominis muscle atrophy, specifically classified as a nerve injury, found on the left anterior abdominal wall. Treatment swiftly ensued, with saline irrigation of the pleural cavity performed through the chest tubes over several weeks. Thankfully, the postoperative course resulted in an uneventful recovery, leading to a discharge in good condition. Follow-up appointments spanning two months revealed an expectation of nerve regeneration and a gradual return to strength in the weakened rectus abdominis.

Introducing Mr. Smith, a patient with a tale of recurring discomfort. Over the past years, he has faced the challenges of ulcerative colitis, a condition accompanied by peripheral polyarthritis. Seeking relief, Mr. Smith recently came to our care, presenting with persistent bouts of diarrhea and joint pain, specifically in his left knee. Diagnostic tests revealed heightened levels of an inflammatory marker, C-reactive protein, as well as a clear synovial fluid without any signs of infection or growth. Based on these findings, we have diagnosed Mr. Smith with inflammatory arthritis, a joint condition primarily affecting his left knee. To address his persistent symptoms, he underwent a total left knee replacement accompanied by arthroscopic debridement and near-total synovectomy. The histopathological examination of the synovial tissue unveiled the presence of 'rice bodies,' indicating active synovitis. Fortunately, Mr. Smith has responded positively to the treatment, experiencing a resolution of knee joint swelling and synovitis. After a smooth postoperative course, he was discharged in good condition. Following up over the course of 12 months, we are thrilled to report that Mr. Smith's colitis and arthritis are in remission, with no notable side effects.

In the midst of a challenging health journey, the patient arrived at our facility with a suite of concerning symptoms: a persistent fever, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and back pain troubling them for the past five days. Remarkably, their neurological functions remained intact. Comprehensive diagnostic investigations revealed a formidable soft tissue mass measuring 91 × 107 × 103 mm, encompassing the vertebrae, ribs, and lung nodules. Further MRI assessment uncovered a paravertebral tumor applying pressure to the spinal cord. The subsequent pathology report confirmed a diagnosis of a malignant giant cell tumor of bone within the lung tissue. To address this complex condition, the patient underwent tumor resection and fixation-reconstruction from T9 to T11, only to face a recurrence, leading to a second tumorectomy from T8 to T9. Despite the challenges encountered, the patient has made steady progress in their lower extremity function through rigorous rehabilitation training. Now, after a recovery marked by resilience and determination, the patient has been discharged in a recovered state. A meticulous follow-up spanning four years has shown encouraging results, with the patient achieving the ability to walk with the aid of crutches and exhibiting growth and development comparable to their peers.

In a case that presented with vomiting and melena, along with the observation of tachycardia and a low hemoglobin level of 6.3 g/dL, a comprehensive evaluation was conducted. The upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed active bleeding from an ulcer on the surface of an elevated lesion situated in the lower portion of the stomach. Further examinations, including endoscopic ultrasonography and computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen, identified a well-demarcated mass with a hypoechoic pattern in the third and fourth layers of the gastric wall. The CT scan confirmed the presence of a mass displaying dense homogeneous enhancement. Based on these findings, the diagnosis was determined to be a gastric submucosal tumor (GT), although the specific type remains unknown. The GT was located on the antral wall of the stomach. Consequently, the patient underwent gastric wedge resection, a surgical procedure that successfully removed the tumor. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in good condition. A follow-up period of ten months revealed no signs of relapse, indicating a positive outcome and ensuring the patient's continued functional status.
